PAA: Why does my septic tank smell?
How do I get rid of septic odor?
Why do I smell sewage in my house?

sources.why: Miami-Dade County septic system maintenance and health requirements
Florida DOH information on septic system health and safety

linkable_points: Septic odors are caused by hydrogen sulfide and other gases produced during waste breakdown in septic systems
Odors inside homes often indicate plumbing vent problems, dry P-traps, or sewer line issues rather than septic tank problems
Outdoor odors around septic tanks usually indicate tank needs pumping, vent problems, or drain field issues
Professional odor diagnosis typically costs $150-$400 in Miami-Dade, while repairs cost $200-$2,000+ depending on cause
Miami's high humidity and heat can make septic odors more noticeable and persistent than in cooler climates
Most septic odors can be resolved with proper maintenance like tank pumping, vent cleaning, or P-trap maintenance
Persistent odors inside homes may indicate sewer gas leaks that require immediate professional attention for health safety
Regular septic maintenance (pumping every 3-5 years) helps prevent odor problems before they develop

competitors.notes: Most competitors offer odor diagnosis and troubleshooting as part of septic service

outline: Intro - What causes septic odors, why they occur, health implications

When to Call Professionals - Signs that require immediate professional service

Miami Environment - How local climate affects odor problems
Related Services - Links to pumping, inspection, cleaning services
FAQs - 7 question-answer pairs addressing PAA questions
cost_methodology: Ranges commonly reported by Miami-Dade licensed contractors. Costs vary based on diagnosis complexity, whether simple fixes or major repairs are needed.
local_factors: Miami's high humidity makes odors more noticeable and can trap smells near ground level
Heat and humidity can accelerate bacterial activity in septic systems, increasing odor production
Heavy rainfall can cause system problems that lead to odors, especially during wet season
High water table in Miami can cause drain field saturation, leading to odor problems
